#### Section 1: Invisible worlds
Materials and phenomena that occur on the nanoscale are, almost by
definition, too small for the human visual sense. Nevertheless, we
really do know their shapes, sizes, and compositions. To obtain this
information, we rely on techniques of **characterization**. Namely, on
the two closely related areas of **spectroscopy** and *imaging*.
Spectroscopy is the processes by which matter is bombarded with some
type of particle or radiation, and the particles that are scattered,
transmitted, or re-emitted are analyzed for clues about the structure.
Imaging techniques use a similar paradigm, but the end goal is not to
produce a quantitative spectrum but a visual image for processing (often
by the human brain). There are many modalities which combine
spectroscopy and imaging in a single instrument. For a video primer to
this chapter, visit 
>>>video(https://youtu.be/N18UhNQmI8o)

One of the things that differentiates science from everyday rational
behavior is that science needs special tools to overcome the limits of
human senses. We can only learn so much about the world from our senses
of sight, smell, hearing, touch, and taste. While we can determine some
things about the structure and properties of matter from our five basic
senses, we need to correlate these observations to information gleaned
from other tools. Nowhere is the augmentation of human senses more
necessary than in nanoengineering, where everything is way too small to
see with even the most powerful optical microscopes. For example, a
nanoparticle or quantum dot might have a diameter of 5 nm, but the
smallest wavelength of light that can be detected by the human eye is
about 400 nm, which corresponds to violet light. So, we are blind to
nanomaterials. That's why we can't see viruses billowing out of people's
mouths and noses, and it's also why we can't see the intricate details
of a computer microprocessor at the level of the transistor, even under
the highest possible magnification with a conventional microscope.

Thus, there is a conundrum posed by the diffraction limit of light. The
way to circumvent this problem is to use particles other than visible
photons, such as electrons, ultraviolet rays, X-rays, or even helium
nuclei. These approaches are analogous to optical microscopy in that
they use wavelike particles to interact with matter, and the image is
created from the ways in which light is absorbed or scattered from the
surface.

Such methods of obtaining images of nanoscale objects are not limited
only to modalities which shine---or blast---light or particles upon the
sample. The other major way in which information is collected about the
composition and structure of nanoscale materials is not by shining a
beam from a distance, but rather by physical contact or near-physical
contact, in methods that are akin not to the sense of vision but to the
sense of touch. Such approaches are referred to collectively as
"scanning probe" techniques. The feature that all scanning probe
instruments have in common is the use of a sharp object which scans
along a surface (like a vinyl or LP player). The tip can be used to plot
the topography, mechanical properties, conductivity, chemical
composition, or other properties of the surface. Finally, there are
techniques which use radiation not to generate images, but to probe the
structure of atoms, molecules, particles, and surfaces. These
spectroscopic modalities rely on the basic physics we have covered in
detail in Chapter 8, so we will begin here.

#### Section 2: Spectroscopic characterization of nanomaterials
As we discussed in Chapter 8 on light-matter interactions, the
confinement of electrons in a nanomaterial gives rise to properties that
are related not only to the composition of the particle but to its
physical dimensions. Thus, it is possible to detect light that is
scattered, absorbed and scattered, or absorbed and re-emitted by the
process of fluorescence or phosphorescence. Alternatively, interrogation
with a high-energy beam of *something* triggers the ejection of some
other type of particle or radiation. The key insight in spectroscopy is
that the energies of these ejected or scattered waves or particles
correspond in a very specific way to the atoms, molecules, or materials
under interrogation.

When taking spectra from particles in solution, where solvent and solute
are totally mixed up, you get a single spectrum containing information
from everything in solution. However, when dealing with solid samples,
it is possible to obtain spectra from one region of the solid at a time.
Such spectra can be used to generate an image by plotting the spatially
resolved intensity of one or more signals. Such an image can be used on
its own or overlayed on top of an image using more conventional
techniques. This modality gives you information about the composition of
the structure and also the location of different atoms or bonding
arrangements between atoms in an image, and hence within an object. For
example, granite is an igneous rock composed of many different mineral
types. Putting a sample of granite in an electron microscope equipped
with an X-ray detector allows you to distinguish the location of the
minerals that make it up.

### 14.2.1. Nuclear magnetic resonance, NMR

Subatomic particles like electrons, protons, and neutrons have a
property known as spin. Remember from high school chemistry, you drew
"up" and "down" arrows when populating atomic orbitals with pairs of
electrons (one up, one down)? That notation was supposed to represent
**spin**. It is a property that allows twice as many electrons to occupy
the same orbital without creating huge repulsive forces by the Pauli
exclusion principle.[^14.2.1] You may remember that when constructing the
orbital energies like 1$s^2$, 2$s^2$, 2$p^6$, and so on, the electrons
are paired antiparallel in their respective orbitals or energy levels.
When spins are unpaired, the particle exhibits magnetic activity.

The concept of spin extends to other subatomic particles as well. For
example, when the nucleus of an atom has an odd number of protons and
neutrons---e.g., $^1$H or $^{13}$C---the nucleus itself can be oriented
in a magnetic field. In fact, it can be thought of as a little bar
magnet with a north and south pole. This magnetically active arrangement
can be exploited to learn something about the chemical environment of
the atom.

The technique for molecular structure determination by exploiting this
inherent magnetism of odd-numbered nuclei is called **nuclear magnetic
resonance (NMR)**. In NMR, a dilute solution of a molecule of interest
is placed inside a strong electromagnet cooled by liquid helium. This
electromagnet aligns all of the magnetic moments in a single direction.
Once aligned, a radio-frequency electromagnetic pulse can be applied.
Some of this radiation is absorbed by the nuclei, which flips the spin
from one orientation to another. As the magnetic moment goes back into
alignment with the field, some energy is released in the form of EM
radiation. This radio-frequency energy is transformed into a spectrum.
The spectrum that is produced gives information on the electromagnetic
environment of the magnetically active nuclei. For example, a hydrogen
atom, which has a total spin of one half because it has an odd number of
nucleons (i.e., a single proton), will resonate at a different frequency
depending on its chemical environment. In fact, $^1$HNMR is by far the
most useful and popular kind of NMR spectroscopy. For many organic
molecules, it is not necessary to use any other spectroscopic technique
to discern the structure.

$^1H$NMR derives its usefulness from the fact that every hydrogen atom
has a different resonant energy depending on the density of electrons
surrounding it. Thus, it is usually possible to piece together the
entire structure based on the precise energy of every hydrogen atom in
the molecule. Moreover, the **chemical shift** of the hydrogen atom is
predictable based on a handful of simple rules. For example, if the
hydrogen atom is attached to an electronegative element like oxygen, the
signal will be *de-shielded* by a predictable amount; if the hydrogen
atom is connected to an electropositive element like silicon, the
resulting signal is said to be *shielded*, also by a predictable amount.
Shielded and de-shielded atoms nuclei can be easily resolved by NMR
spectroscopy, with the resolution increasing with the strength of the
magnetic field. The strength of the signal (the area under the curve, or
the *integral*) also corresponds to how many atoms of a particular type
are within a molecule.

To convert from the standard output of NMR software, where the signals
are given in parts per million (ppm) to frequency of the emitted signal
(and equivalently, energy), one uses the following formulae, equations
(14.1) and (14.2)

(Equation 14.1)
$$\delta_{\text{Hz}} = \delta_{\text{ppm}} \times \text{frequency}_{\text{MHz}}$$

(Equation 14.2) $$E = h \times \nu$$

where $\delta_{\text{Hz}}$ is the chemical shift in Hz,
$\delta_{\text{ppm}}$ is the chemical shift in ppm,
$\text{frequency}_{\text{MHz}}$ is the operating frequency of the NMR
spectrometer in MHz, $E$ is energy $h$ is Planck's constant, and $\nu$
is frequency in Hz.

The NMR spectrum can also give information as to the mutual arrangement
or location of atoms attached to molecules at different points. They do
this by *through bond* or *through space* **coupling**. There are many
excellent references on the collection and interpretation of NMR spectra
and we will not go into here. See Figure (14.1) below for a couple of
examples of molecules matched to spectra.

### 14.2.2. Ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy, UV-vis

One of the most common forms of spectroscopy involves the use of
ultraviolet and visible wavelengths of light to probe electronic
transitions in the molecules or particles. Photons in the UV-vis range
tend to have energies commensurate with the band gaps of molecules,
particles, and surfaces. That is, absorption of photons that correspond
to the promotion of electrons from the valence band to the conduction
band (when talking about inorganic materials) or from the highest
occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular
orbital (LUMO) (when talking about molecules). Given that the energies
of photons absorbed correspond to the transitions of electrons between
energy levels, UV-vis spectroscopy is often called **electronic
absorption spectroscopy**. Figure (14.2) shows the key features of a
UV-vis spectrum.

(Figure 14.2) 
>>>image(UV-vis.png.0)

The UV-vis spectrum is usually plotted with absorption on the $y$-axis
as a function of either wavelength (in nm) or energy (in eV). The
convention used weirdly depends on who is plotting the data: chemists,
biologists, and some engineers tend to plot the absorption as a function
of wavelength, while physicists and other engineers plot it as a
function of energy. Since wavelength is inversely proportional to
energy, the plots appear as mirror images of each other.[^14.2.2] Note that
while the differences between energy levels correspond to discrete
photon energies, the absorption spectra nevertheless appear as smoothed
out curves, rather than lines. The broadening of the spectrum arises
first from the *density of states* below the valence band and above the
conduction band. Other effects that lead to broadening involve
perturbations of the energy levels caused by molecular collisions with
each other and with solvent molecules, formation of energy levels
spanning multiple molecules from supramolecular organization (e.g.,
crystallization), and fluctuations of the energetic levels due to
electrostatic (e.g., van der Waals) forces. Despite the broadness of the
absorption profile, it is common practice to take the onset of
absorption as corresponding to the lowest energy photon absorbable by
the system and thus equivalent to the band gap. Usually, one takes the
slope tangent to the beginning of the curve and extrapolates toward the
$x$-axis, as shown in Figure (14.2). The $x$-intercept is taken as the
band gap.

UV-vis spectroscopy can be used to measure effects beyond the bandgaps
of molecules and semiconductors. For example, the localized surface
plasmon resonances (LSPRs) of metallic nanoparticles often also lie in
the ultraviolet or visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum. When
placed in solution, colloidal metallic nanoparticles such as nanowires,
nanocubes, and nanospheres absorb and scatter wavelengths of light that
depend on the shape of the nanoparticle and the atoms(s) of which it is
composed. Recall that anisotropic nanoparticles like wires will have
multiple LSPRs, one for each dimension (a spherical or cubic particle
would have only a single resonance). The smaller dimensions will
resonate at higher energies than the larger ones. Thus, in solution,
where the particles are spinning and tumbling around randomly, all of
the LSPRs will be visible at once. However, if one deposits such
structures on glass or silicon using shearing forces during the
deposition, it is possible to get the particles to line up. Such
deposited structures will exhibit **birefringence**---in which polarized
light will trigger the LSPRs unequally. By using light with different
polarizations, it is possible to tease out the energies of the LSPRs
along the different axes (Figure (14.3)).

(Figure 14.3) 
>>>image(LSPR.png.0)

Finally, we note that such absorption behavior arising from electronic
transitions and LSPRs are not strictly limited to the range of photons
in the UV-vis region. In fact, many kinds of semiconductor nanocrystals
absorb in the near-infraried (NIR), and plasmonic nanoparticles with
dimensions of more than a few hundred nanometers also resonate in this
range. Thus, the technique is often referred to as UV-vis-NIR.

### 14.2.3. X-ray photoemission spectroscopy, XPS

We have seen above how photons can affect transitions of electrons from
one band to another within a solid. However, with high enough incident
energies of photons, electrons can be completely ejected from the
surface of a material. This phenomenon is called the **photoelectric
effect** (Figure (14.4) and was the basis of Albert Einstein's sole
Nobel Prize.[^14.2.3] In this theory, the kinetic energy of an electron
ejected from the surface of a solid is given by

(Equation 14.3) $$E = h\nu - \phi$$

(Figure 14.4) 
>>>image(photoelectric.png.0)

where $E$ is the energy (kinetic energy, because the electron is
moving), $h$ and $\nu$ are Planck's constant and the frequency of the
incoming photon, and $\phi$ is the **work function** of the surface. The
work function is conceptually similar to the **ionization energy**.
However, the ionization energy refers to the energy required to extract
the outermost electron from an atom in the gas phase, whereas the work
function is the energy required to extract an electron from the surface
of a material made of many atoms. The work function is always less than
the ionization energy for individual atoms of the same element. In part,
this difference arises because of the strong electrostatic attraction of
an electron to an ion in the gas phase; in a solid, the positive charge
left behind can more or less freely delocalize. Moreover, for an atom in
the gas phase, the ionization energy is taken as the energy of an
electron in the outermost (highest energy) occupied orbital. In a solid
metal, the outermost electrons are involved in strong metallic bonding.
In metallic solids, the energy of the outermost electrons is increased
to a value called the **Fermi level**, which represents the average
energy of the conduction electrons. The Fermi level is sometimes called
the *electrochemical potential* of the electrons.

When a photon of an energy equal to or greater than the Fermi level of
the metal surface, an electron is ejected. The finding illustrates one
aspect of the nature of light, namely the relationship between energy
and intensity. Among other observations, Einstein noted that increasing
the brightness or intensity of the light does not increase the energy of
the ejected **photoelectrons**, but it does increase their number. This
insight into the energies of photoelectrons---namely that they are
quantized and always have the same energies---is the basis for elemental
analysis by a technique called **X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
(XPS)**.

In the traditional conception of measurements of the photoelectric
effect, the incident beam is in the ultraviolet or visible region of the
electromagnetic spectrum. Photons with wavelengths in this range can
knock loose electrons in the highest energy atomic orbitals, or at the
Fermi level of the metal. However, if a beam made of much higher energy
photons is used, such as a beam of X-rays, it is possible to penetrate
much deeper into the atomic structures. In XPS, a high-energy beam of
photons (X-rays, $\lambda$ = 0.834 nm, E = 1486 eV, from an aluminum
source) blasts the surface of the sample. The collisions cause many
electrons to be ejected. These electrons can originate from any
electronic energy level within the atom. Recall from your chemistry
class that these energy levels correspond to the levels of 1s, 2s, 3p,
and so on. The further inside the atom, toward the nucleus, the more
tightly held the electron, and thus the greater energy needed to eject
it. However, once the electron is ejected, it arrives at a detector with
*less* energy than those which were on the outside---i.e., higher
energy---of the atom. The reason is that it took a lot of energy to
dislodge the electron from the inner core, as implied by equation
(14.3).

Given that every atom of any element has exactly the same energies for
electrons, the energies of the electrons ejected create a spectrum akin
to a fingerprint. Thus, it is possible to determine the elemental
composition of a material, at least near the surface. (The technique
works for the first 10 atomic layers or so.) See Figure (14.5) for an
illustration of a typical XPS spectrum.

(Figure 14.5) 
>>>image(XPS.png.0)

### 14.2.4. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy

A related technique to XPS is **energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy
(EDS)**. The major difference, at least operationally, is that in XPS
the incident beam is an X-ray and the emitted beam is made of electrons;
in EDS, the incident beam is an electron beam whereas the emitted beam
is X-ray photons. In brief, an energetic beam of electrons strikes the
atoms that make up a material, see Figure (14.5). These energetic
collisions knock inner-shell electrons into free space. So far, EDS
sounds a lot like XPS. However, it is not the ejected electrons are
detected, but rather *the photons released when outer-shell electrons
fill in the holes left by ejected inner-shell electrons*. These photons
are generally in the X-ray region of the electromagnetic spectrum. As in
XPS, the spectrum of energies produced creates a pattern unique to each
atom, like a fingerprint.

The EDS process is generally performed inside of a scanning electron
microscope (SEM, described in detail in the next section). The beam
scanned across the sample to generate the image also triggers the
production of X-rays. Thus, the SEM equipped with an X-ray detector can
simultaneously perform the imaging and the elemental analysis. It is
thus possible to overlay an elemental map on top of an electron
micrograph (image). In this type of composite image, different elements
are indicated using different colors. Electron microscopy plus EDS
analysis is a powerful tool to examine nanomaterials and the nanoscale
structures of larger samples.

    occupy exactly the same space---they *exclude* each other.

[^14.2.2]: Recall that one can convert between wavelength and energy using
    the conversion factor of 1240 eV nm. Simply take the quantity you
    have and divide it into the conversion factor to obtain the other
    quantity. Thus a photon with an energy of 2 eV has a wavelength of
    620 nm, and vice versa.

#### Section 3: Taking pictures of nanomaterials using the scattering of light and charged particles
The goal in characterizing nanomaterials is to prove you have what you
think you have. Spectroscopy is great at providing clues as to the
atomic and molecular level details of materials. However, it is not
always possible to use spectroscopic techniques to determine the shapes
and sizes of particles without other information. Moreover, it is
generally impossible to determine the arrangements of particles in a
solid structure in either two or three dimensions using spectroscopy
alone. Imaging techniques, on the other hand, can provide this
information. In general, an image is produced by the observation of
reflected or transmitted waves. These waves can be in the form of
photons, electrons, or even other charged particles. Often, multiple
imaging modalities are used on the same sample. Images from multiple
techniques can also be combined to form a **composite image**.

### 14.3.1. Optical microscopy

Pretty much everyone reading this book has used an optical (that is,
light) microscope in a high school science class. When I was a kid, I
was given a used Tasco microscope with 5x, 10x, 20x, and 50x objectives.
It came with a single slide containing dried algae cells. I explored
every square micron of that sample. It was like a microscopic universe.
Later, at a garage sale, I picked up a box of fixed samples in
microscope slides which included several slices of plant and animal
tissue. I even tried to generate my own samples but didn't have the
ability to make ultrathin sections, so I couldn't get light to pass
through my samples, as my microscope was equipped with illumination from
the bottom only.[^14.3.1]

A microscope contains many lenses whose basic function is as a
magnifying glass. In short, a lens which is convex on both sides (like
an almond) bends light rays in such a way as to make the object appear
larger when the reflected light enters the eye. A modern optical
microscope contains many such lenses which compounds the magnification
of each lens, i.e., a **compound microscope**. For example, a 10$\times$
**objective** and a 10$\times$ **eyepiece** yields a total magnification
of 100$\times$.

The total achievable magnification of optical microscopy is about
1,000$\times$. The smallest sized object resolvable by an optical
microscope is around 1 $\mu$m; any smaller and the object just blends in
with the background. The reason for the inability to resolve features
any smaller is because of the **diffraction limit** of light (which
incidentally also applies to beams of other kinds of photons and
subatomic particles). The diffraction limit is a consequence of the
wave-like nature of light. Just as waves on the surface of a pool
diffract or bend around corners, light bends around objects and makes
the edges appear blurry. When there is more "blur" than "object,"
nothing is seen. While more powerful lenses can be used which boosts the
nominal level of magnification beyond 1000$\times$, the microscope will
still not be able to resolve smaller features, at least when one is
using visible wavelengths of light under **bright field** illumination.
The term *bright field* refers to the fact that the objective lens
collects all light that is reflected (when illuminated from the top,
used for opaque specimens), transmitted (when illuminated from the
bottom, used for transparent specimens, or scattered from the specimen.
The intensity of the reflected or transmitted light dominates the
scattered light.

As a student working in nanotechnology, however, my favorite mode of
optical microscopy was not bright field but **dark field** imaging. In
dark field---which in nanoengineering is generally used to image samples
immobilized on an opaque or reflective substrate like silicon---it is
possible to see, if not resolve, objects that are much smaller than 1
$\mu$m. Dark field imaging works by blocking the path of light rays that
are reflected or transmitted directly from the specimen to the eye. Only
light that is scattered with a lateral component is collected and makes
its way to the objective. Dark field imaging is particularly good at
visualizing the edges of objects, as these discontinuities in materials
light up like glowing hot filaments (they are not actually glowing or
hot). Moreover, nanoparticles made of metals actually scatter light at
the wavelengths of their localized surface plasmon resonances. Thus, a
gold nanowire with a 20 nm width appears a different color than a gold
nanowire with a 30 nm width. Such differences in color can easily be
resolved by the human eye.[^14.3.2]

#### Fluorescence microscopy

Other modalities of optical microscopy include **fluorescence
microscopy** and various forms of **polarization microscopy** (discussed
in the next paragraph). Fluorescence microscopy is a ubiquitous tool in
cell biology. In particular, cells and tissues can be imaged by
fluorescent stains, proteins (e.g., **green fluorescent protein, GFP**),
and nanoparticles. Fluorescence microscopy uses a higher energy
excitation beam to stimulate fluorescent emission in the fluorescent
species. The reflected light used for excitation, along with the emitted
fluorescent light, travels through a **band pass filter**, which is
tuned to block the higher energy used for excitation. Thus, what results
is an image in which the fluorescent species light up. In biology, this
technique is commonly used to identify cells that carry certain genes,
since the gene for the fluorescent protein can be co-located in the
cell.

As you might imagine, fluorescence microscopy is highly valuable in
experiments involving quantum dots and other fluorescent nanoparticles
as imaging agents. For example, it can be used to see how quantum dots
are distributed in cells between organelles. It can also be used to see
what sizes, shapes, and chemical functionalities lead to this
partitioning. It is thus an immensely important tool in basic research
in nanomedicine and nanoparticle-based strategies for biomedical
imaging.

#### Polarization Microscopy

Polarization microscopy is a technique that takes advantage of the
property of **birefringence**, or unequal absorption of a material
sample with respect to **polarization**. Polarization refers to the
direction of oscillation of electromagnetic waves. That is, the
polarization is with respect to the angle of the amplitude of these
transverse waves. Materials develop the property of birefringence when
they have structures exhibiting a high degree of **anisotropy**. That
is, a preferential direction of the components. For example, a box of
uncooked spaghetti with all the individual noodles aligned parallel to
one another is highly anisotropic. Once the spaghetti is cooked and
looks like a jumbled mess in the pot, it is said to be **isotropic**.
When the structures that make up the solid are themselves highly
anisotropic---meaning that they are longer than they are wide---there is
the potential for birefringence.

Two mechanisms of polarization that have come up so far in this book are
**wire grid polarization** and **absorptive polarization**. A wire grid
polarizer is made of an array of thin, parallel wires on a transparent
substrate. These wires have widths of less than 1 $\mu$m, with a spacing
of roughly equal width. When unpolarized light is incident upon these
wires, the electromagnetic waves cause the conduction electrons in the
metal to slosh (i.e., oscillate) back and forth. Since the lengths of
the wires are, needless to say, longer than the widths, only
polarizations parallel to the lengths can trigger this sloshing. Light
of this polarization is thus reflected or scattered, just as the flat
metal surface behind the glass plane of a mirror does. Light polarized
perpendicularly to the parallel wires does not trigger the oscillation
of the conduction electrons of the wires. The reason is that the
submicron, transverse widths of the metal wires are too short to support
these oscillations. Thus, components of light with polarizations
perpendicular to the wires are transmitted through.[^14.3.3] Figure (14.6)
shows a schematic diagram of the light that is blocked by and
transmitted through a wire grid polarizer.

(Figure 14.6) 
>>>image(polarization.png.0)

Absorptive polarization is conceptually similar to wire grid
polarization. The major difference is that where wire grid polarization
uses metal wires to reflect light, absorptive polarization uses aligned
molecules to absorb it. There are many classes of materials that can
behave as absorptive polarizers. Polarizers derived from organic media
(e.g., polymers) are often called **Polaroids** after the company that
developed them. These organic polarizers are often based on a polymer
film (often polyvinyl alcohol) that is solidified while it is being
stretched. Thus, the molecules align along the stretched axis. If these
polymer chains are not inherently absorbing, they can be chemically
oxidized, using, e.g., iodine, to render it so. These Polaroid films are
ubiquitous in liquid crystal displays. (In fact, you are probably
looking through at least one Polaroid film if you are reading the
electronic version of this book!) Another common application of organic
polarizers are in polarized sunglasses, which reduce glare originating
from flat reflective surfaces like windshields, road surfaces, and
water.[^14.3.4]

All of the above is to say that if a polarizer is inserted between the
light source and the sample, the polarized components of the sample
appear to "pop out." Thus, it is possible to differentiate domains of
materials which have different atomic or molecular orientations, even
though it is not possible to see the atoms or molecules themselves.
Another technique, called **cross-polarization**, can be used to
visualize structures with radially symmetric orientations, like a
snowflake. The "Maltese cross" that appears when a cross section of a
polymer **spherulite** is placed in between two polarizers oriented 90
$^{\circ}$ from each other is a result of this effect. Namely, polarized
light incident on the sample from the first polarizer is partially
rotated by the specimen, and then rotated once more by the polarizer
between the specimen and the eyepiece.

When I occasionally have visitors to my lab, they may notice my compound
optical microscope (one of my first purchases as a new professor!).
These visitors sometimes express disbelief that information about
molecular and nanoscale structure can be derived from plain-vanilla
optical microscopy! Then I tell them about the features that appear
under dark-field and fluorescence microscopy, and what information can
be gleaned simply from inserting one or more polarizers into the beam
path. However, all such information provides indirect evidence of
structure; one has to know the theory of light-matter interactions in
order to divine something about the size, structure, or composition of
the specimen. To truly "visualize" the sample, beams with wavelengths
much smaller than the wavelength of visible light are needed. To that
end, we turn to microscopy using beams of electrons.

### 14.3.2. Scanning electron microscopy

The history of electron microscopy can be traced back to de Broglie, who
postulated the **wave-particle duality** of matter. This postulate
suggests that all matter has a wavelength, which is inversely
proportional to its mass. It is one of the fundamental postulates of
quantum mechanics. Specifically, the wavelength of any particle can be
shown by (14.4) to be

(Equation 14.4) $$\lambda = \frac{h}{mv}$$

where $m$ is the mass of the particle and $v$ is its velocity. So, for
particles that have finite mass, very small wavelengths are possible. If
the wavelength of an interrogating beam is brought down to a size
smaller than the object being imaged, it is possible to resolve the fine
details of its structure. Thus, most images of viruses, catalysts, and
transistors in integrated circuits are obtained not with optical
microscopy but with **scanning electron microscopy (SEM)** (Figure
(14.7)).

(Figure 14.7) 
>>>image(SEM.png.0)

In SEM, a beam of electrons is generated by putting several kV of
electrical potential across a metal (e.g., tungsten) filament. A current
flows through the filament, and the heat generated causes some of the
electrons to be ejected. Another electrical potential directs the beam
in the direction of a **stage**, which holds the **specimen**.
Electromagnets near the electron source (**electron gun**) are used to
guide and focus the electron beam. The beam is **rastered** or
**scanned** across the surface of the sample; electrons or X-rays are
ejected from each location. The characteristics of the ejected species
are mapped in grayscale to the image. Thus, the image of the object is
created pixel by pixel, not all at once as in optical microscopy or, as
we shall see, transmission electron microscopy (TEM).

The beam of electrons scanning across a surface is not necessarily a
gentle process, as one might read Braille with one's fingertips. Rather,
it is a harsh interrogation; it has to be in order to eject electrons
and photons---in whose quantized energies much can be gleaned---from the
specimen. Nevertheless, the depth at which interaction occurs is limited
to a few nanometers for metals (which quickly dissipate charge) and a
few tens of nanometers for insulators (which do not). The interactions
between the incident beam and the atoms comprising the specimen cause
several types of particles and electromagnetic radiation to be ejected.
These scattered species and their characteristics are detected by a
number of **detectors** in the SEM chamber. Sometimes, information from
more than one detector is combined to make a composite image.

Arguably, the most useful things ejected by the surface after
interaction with the incident electron beam are **secondary electrons**.
A secondary electron is an electron that arises due to an ionization of
an atom in the sample. It is kind of like a photoelectron generated in
XPS, except that the excitation source is an electron beam, rather than
a beam of X-rays. Moreover, multiple secondary electrons can be ejected
from a single incident electron, as the result of an "avalanche" of
collisions within the sample.

There are two types of detectors for secondary electrons, which differ
mainly in their location within the chamber, and the information that
can be taken from the images they produce. The first type is the
**Everhart-Thornley detector**, which is located above the stage and off
to the side. It is pointed at the specimen at an angle. The second type
is the **in-lens detector**, which as the name implies is located in the
same column of hardware that also produces the electron beam. The
detector is annular (like a donut) so that the beam can pass through its
hole from the tungsten filament on the way to the sample. In general,
the in-lens detector is better at resolving fine features of the
morphology, while the Everhart-Thornley detector produces a better image
of the topography. It is not uncommon for the user to toggle back and
forth between the two detectors and watch the image change in real time.

Other ejected species include **backscattered electrons (BSE)**, which
are electrons originating from the incident beam, but which have been
scattered elastically, like billiard balls. These electrons can be
detected by tweaking the settings on a typical secondary electron
detector, or, more commonly, using a detector that is dedicated to BSE.
Detectors for BSE provide good contrast for elements with different
atomic numbers ("$Z$ contrast"). Backscattered electrons can also lose
energy; the difference in energy between the incident and reflected
electrons can be used for **electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS)**.
Another species ejected, which we have already discussed in our
discussion of EDS, is X-rays. The techniques of EELS and EDS are often
treated as being complementary to each other. EDS excels at elemental
composition and is extremely easy to implement and interpret, while EELS
is sensitive to the ionization state and bonding environment of the atom
under investigation.

A few notes about the practicality and hardware used for SEM. Because of
the reactive nature of electron beams and scattered species, SEM must be
carried out at low pressure. Additionally, biological samples must be
dehydrated so that they don't explode when the chamber is pumped down to
base pressure. Electrically insulating samples must be coated with metal
to avoid **charging**---the accumulation of charge in the sample by the
electron beam---and eventual degradation of the sample. Coating is
generally performed using a relatively inexpensive benchtop sputter
deposition system. The most common coating metals are gold,
gold/palladium alloy, and platinum. Platinum has the smallest grain size
and is thus used for the highest-resolution applications, but it is
expensive. Variants of SEM which permit the introduction of gas in the
specimen chamber to circumvent the need to coat the sample are common.
Conventional SEM instruments can be equipped with a *variable pressure*
mode, in which a small amount of water is injected into the chamber to
dissipate charge on the sample. There is also full-on environmental SEM
(ESEM), in which a sophisticated pumping system is used in conjunction
with modified analysis of secondary electrons to examine specimens in
conditions resembling ambient air.

#### Helium ion microscopy

Remember that the de Broglie wavelength of a beam of particles is
inversely proportional to its mass. A helium nucleus, He$^{2+}$, has a
much larger mass than an electron, and thus can have a correspondingly
smaller wavelength when accelerated toward a specimen. This property is
the basis of **helium ion microscopy**, which can be considered a
variant of SEM. In this type of imaging, a beam of helium ions is
rastered over a surface. Collisions of these ions with the sample
produce many of the same effects that occur in SEM: generation of
secondary electrons, X-rays, and so forth. However, given the smaller
wavelength of a helium ion as compared to an electron, helium ion
microscopy is capable of significantly greater resolution and depth of
focus (i.e., how much of the depth of the sample can be in focus at
once).

### 14.3.3. Transmission electron microscopy, TEM

The other major modality in which beams of electrons are used to obtain
images of nanostructured materials is **transmission electron microscopy
(TEM)**. Like SEM, TEM also uses an electron beam, but it is perhaps
more conceptually similar to optical microscopy in cases of the latter
when the beam of light is transmitted through a thin transparent sample.
In TEM, a specimen of material is made into a thin sheet with a
thickness of \<100 nm. For biological samples, samples are created by
embedding cells or tissues into a resin (e.g., epoxy), and sectioning
this composite structure (the "block") with an **ultramicrotome**.[^14.3.5]
Since TEM works best if there is contrast between light and heavy
elements, the thin sections are "stained" with a reagent containing a
heavy element, such as osmium. In materials science, ultramicrotomy can
also be used, but because brittle samples sometimes crumble during the
mechanical sectioning process, it is somewhat more common to obtain thin
samples using **ion milling** (a relatively inexpensive method for
general purpose thinning) or **focused ion beam (FIB) milling** (in
which a beam of ions can carve thin slabs of materials in precise
locations, but which must be done in a vacuum chamber under simultaneous
SEM imaging).

Once obtained, the thin specimens are suspended on a disk containing one
or more apertures. The disk is commonly made of copper or silicon
nitride. The apertures form the window through which the specimen is
"illuminated" by the electron beam. The transmitted beam is then
projected on a screen that historically was something akin to
photographic film but is now an array of semiconductor-based detectors,
sort of like the detector in a digital camera.

Once the beam passes through the sample, a wide range of information can
be collected. First, the shapes of nanoparticles---including quantum
dots, nanocrystals, viruses, cellular organelles, and other
materials---can be readily obtained. If the structure is crystalline,
the electron beam can generate a diffraction pattern akin to that
obtained using X-ray diffraction. From this diffraction pattern, the
atomic spacing and crystallographic features of the specimen may be
measured. The TEM instrument may also be outfitted with several of the
ancillary detectors found in SEM. For example, it is possible to obtain
energy dispersive X-ray spectra (EDS) from a TEM sample, so that one can
determine the elemental composition of a specimen, not just its physical
dimensions.

Recent developments in TEM include the increasingly sophisticated
ability to visualize organic molecules, even at the single-molecule
level. Moreover, new types of TEM cells can permit the loading and flow
of liquid through a thin visualization chamber. These semi-transparent
"windows" allow for the direct observation of molecular dynamics and
self-assembly processes in real time. The power of liquid-cell TEM is
that images and even movies can be obtained in contexts that resemble
the "natural"---non immobilized---environments for such specimens. The
consequences of this type of dynamic imaging are profound. New
approaches to nanoscale drug delivery can be engineered and investigated
without relying on indirect evidence of the dynamics; the conformation
of large molecules in solution can be confirmed by direct observation
for the first time; and even the course of some types of chemical
reactions involving nanoscale structures.

### 14.3.4. Dynamic light scattering, DLS

Another technique deserves mentioning here, though its theoretical
complexity precludes a complete discussion. The sizes of colloidal
particles in liquids---including the sizes and dynamics of polymer
blobs---can be determined using the technique of **dynamic light
scattering (DLS)**. In brief, DLS operates by shining an incident laser
beam through a sample. All parts of the sample undergo elastic
(Rayleigh) scattering in all directions. The scattered beam gets spread
over a large area on a screen or detector in the form of dots or
speckles. If the laser is pulsed at a fixed interval, the evolution of
the **speckle pattern** over time provides information as to the
dynamics of the molecules in solution. Additionally, the spacing between
the speckles is related to the sizes of the nanoparticles in solution.
Finer-grained analysis can even provide measurements of the
intramolecular spacing between elements of the same molecule (i.e.,
between monomer residues of the same polymer chain).

#### Section 2: Spectroscopic characterization of nanomaterials
As we discussed in Chapter 8 on light-matter interactions, the
confinement of electrons in a nanomaterial gives rise to properties that
are related not only to the composition of the particle but to its
physical dimensions. Thus, it is possible to detect light that is
scattered, absorbed and scattered, or absorbed and re-emitted by the
process of fluorescence or phosphorescence. Alternatively, interrogation
with a high-energy beam of *something* triggers the ejection of some
other type of particle or radiation. The key insight in spectroscopy is
that the energies of these ejected or scattered waves or particles
correspond in a very specific way to the atoms, molecules, or materials
under interrogation.

When taking spectra from particles in solution, where solvent and solute
are totally mixed up, you get a single spectrum containing information
from everything in solution. However, when dealing with solid samples,
it is possible to obtain spectra from one region of the solid at a time.
Such spectra can be used to generate an image by plotting the spatially
resolved intensity of one or more signals. Such an image can be used on
its own or overlayed on top of an image using more conventional
techniques. This modality gives you information about the composition of
the structure and also the location of different atoms or bonding
arrangements between atoms in an image, and hence within an object. For
example, granite is an igneous rock composed of many different mineral
types. Putting a sample of granite in an electron microscope equipped
with an X-ray detector allows you to distinguish the location of the
minerals that make it up.

### 14.2.1. Nuclear magnetic resonance, NMR

Subatomic particles like electrons, protons, and neutrons have a
property known as spin. Remember from high school chemistry, you drew
"up" and "down" arrows when populating atomic orbitals with pairs of
electrons (one up, one down)? That notation was supposed to represent
**spin**. It is a property that allows twice as many electrons to occupy
the same orbital without creating huge repulsive forces by the Pauli
exclusion principle.[^14.2.1] You may remember that when constructing the
orbital energies like 1$s^2$, 2$s^2$, 2$p^6$, and so on, the electrons
are paired antiparallel in their respective orbitals or energy levels.
When spins are unpaired, the particle exhibits magnetic activity.

The concept of spin extends to other subatomic particles as well. For
example, when the nucleus of an atom has an odd number of protons and
neutrons---e.g., $^1$H or $^{13}$C---the nucleus itself can be oriented
in a magnetic field. In fact, it can be thought of as a little bar
magnet with a north and south pole. This magnetically active arrangement
can be exploited to learn something about the chemical environment of
the atom.

The technique for molecular structure determination by exploiting this
inherent magnetism of odd-numbered nuclei is called **nuclear magnetic
resonance (NMR)**. In NMR, a dilute solution of a molecule of interest
is placed inside a strong electromagnet cooled by liquid helium. This
electromagnet aligns all of the magnetic moments in a single direction.
Once aligned, a radio-frequency electromagnetic pulse can be applied.
Some of this radiation is absorbed by the nuclei, which flips the spin
from one orientation to another. As the magnetic moment goes back into
alignment with the field, some energy is released in the form of EM
radiation. This radio-frequency energy is transformed into a spectrum.
The spectrum that is produced gives information on the electromagnetic
environment of the magnetically active nuclei. For example, a hydrogen
atom, which has a total spin of one half because it has an odd number of
nucleons (i.e., a single proton), will resonate at a different frequency
depending on its chemical environment. In fact, $^1$HNMR is by far the
most useful and popular kind of NMR spectroscopy. For many organic
molecules, it is not necessary to use any other spectroscopic technique
to discern the structure.

$^1H$NMR derives its usefulness from the fact that every hydrogen atom
has a different resonant energy depending on the density of electrons
surrounding it. Thus, it is usually possible to piece together the
entire structure based on the precise energy of every hydrogen atom in
the molecule. Moreover, the **chemical shift** of the hydrogen atom is
predictable based on a handful of simple rules. For example, if the
hydrogen atom is attached to an electronegative element like oxygen, the
signal will be *de-shielded* by a predictable amount; if the hydrogen
atom is connected to an electropositive element like silicon, the
resulting signal is said to be *shielded*, also by a predictable amount.
Shielded and de-shielded atoms nuclei can be easily resolved by NMR
spectroscopy, with the resolution increasing with the strength of the
magnetic field. The strength of the signal (the area under the curve, or
the *integral*) also corresponds to how many atoms of a particular type
are within a molecule.

To convert from the standard output of NMR software, where the signals
are given in parts per million (ppm) to frequency of the emitted signal
(and equivalently, energy), one uses the following formulae, equations
(14.1) and (14.2)

(Equation 14.1)
$$\delta_{\text{Hz}} = \delta_{\text{ppm}} \times \text{frequency}_{\text{MHz}}$$

(Equation 14.2) $$E = h \times \nu$$

where $\delta_{\text{Hz}}$ is the chemical shift in Hz,
$\delta_{\text{ppm}}$ is the chemical shift in ppm,
$\text{frequency}_{\text{MHz}}$ is the operating frequency of the NMR
spectrometer in MHz, $E$ is energy $h$ is Planck's constant, and $\nu$
is frequency in Hz.

The NMR spectrum can also give information as to the mutual arrangement
or location of atoms attached to molecules at different points. They do
this by *through bond* or *through space* **coupling**. There are many
excellent references on the collection and interpretation of NMR spectra
and we will not go into here. See Figure (14.1) below for a couple of

### 14.2.2. Ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy, UV-vis

One of the most common forms of spectroscopy involves the use of
ultraviolet and visible wavelengths of light to probe electronic
transitions in the molecules or particles. Photons in the UV-vis range
tend to have energies commensurate with the band gaps of molecules,
particles, and surfaces. That is, absorption of photons that correspond
to the promotion of electrons from the valence band to the conduction
band (when talking about inorganic materials) or from the highest
occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular
orbital (LUMO) (when talking about molecules). Given that the energies
of photons absorbed correspond to the transitions of electrons between
energy levels, UV-vis spectroscopy is often called **electronic
absorption spectroscopy**. Figure (14.2) shows the key features of a
UV-vis spectrum.

(Figure 14.2) 
>>>image(UV-vis.png.0)

The UV-vis spectrum is usually plotted with absorption on the $y$-axis
as a function of either wavelength (in nm) or energy (in eV). The
convention used weirdly depends on who is plotting the data: chemists,
biologists, and some engineers tend to plot the absorption as a function
of wavelength, while physicists and other engineers plot it as a
function of energy. Since wavelength is inversely proportional to
energy, the plots appear as mirror images of each other.[^14.2.2] Note that
while the differences between energy levels correspond to discrete
photon energies, the absorption spectra nevertheless appear as smoothed
out curves, rather than lines. The broadening of the spectrum arises
first from the *density of states* below the valence band and above the
conduction band. Other effects that lead to broadening involve
perturbations of the energy levels caused by molecular collisions with
each other and with solvent molecules, formation of energy levels
spanning multiple molecules from supramolecular organization (e.g.,
crystallization), and fluctuations of the energetic levels due to
electrostatic (e.g., van der Waals) forces. Despite the broadness of the
absorption profile, it is common practice to take the onset of
absorption as corresponding to the lowest energy photon absorbable by
the system and thus equivalent to the band gap. Usually, one takes the
slope tangent to the beginning of the curve and extrapolates toward the
$x$-axis, as shown in Figure (14.2). The $x$-intercept is taken as the
band gap.

UV-vis spectroscopy can be used to measure effects beyond the bandgaps
of molecules and semiconductors. For example, the localized surface
plasmon resonances (LSPRs) of metallic nanoparticles often also lie in
the ultraviolet or visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum. When
placed in solution, colloidal metallic nanoparticles such as nanowires,
nanocubes, and nanospheres absorb and scatter wavelengths of light that
depend on the shape of the nanoparticle and the atoms(s) of which it is
composed. Recall that anisotropic nanoparticles like wires will have
multiple LSPRs, one for each dimension (a spherical or cubic particle
would have only a single resonance). The smaller dimensions will
resonate at higher energies than the larger ones. Thus, in solution,
where the particles are spinning and tumbling around randomly, all of
the LSPRs will be visible at once. However, if one deposits such
structures on glass or silicon using shearing forces during the
deposition, it is possible to get the particles to line up. Such
deposited structures will exhibit **birefringence**---in which polarized
light will trigger the LSPRs unequally. By using light with different
polarizations, it is possible to tease out the energies of the LSPRs
along the different axes (Figure (14.3)).

(Figure 14.3)

Finally, we note that such absorption behavior arising from electronic
transitions and LSPRs are not strictly limited to the range of photons
in the UV-vis region. In fact, many kinds of semiconductor nanocrystals
absorb in the near-infraried (NIR), and plasmonic nanoparticles with
dimensions of more than a few hundred nanometers also resonate in this
range. Thus, the technique is often referred to as UV-vis-NIR.

### 14.2.3. X-ray photoemission spectroscopy, XPS

We have seen above how photons can affect transitions of electrons from
one band to another within a solid. However, with high enough incident
energies of photons, electrons can be completely ejected from the
surface of a material. This phenomenon is called the **photoelectric
effect** (Figure (14.4) and was the basis of Albert Einstein's sole
Nobel Prize.[^14.2.3] In this theory, the kinetic energy of an electron
ejected from the surface of a solid is given by

(Equation 14.3) $$E = h\nu - \phi$$

(Figure 14.4) 
>>>image(photoelectric.png.0)

where $E$ is the energy (kinetic energy, because the electron is
moving), $h$ and $\nu$ are Planck's constant and the frequency of the
incoming photon, and $\phi$ is the **work function** of the surface. The
work function is conceptually similar to the **ionization energy**.
However, the ionization energy refers to the energy required to extract
the outermost electron from an atom in the gas phase, whereas the work
function is the energy required to extract an electron from the surface
of a material made of many atoms. The work function is always less than
the ionization energy for individual atoms of the same element. In part,
this difference arises because of the strong electrostatic attraction of
an electron to an ion in the gas phase; in a solid, the positive charge
left behind can more or less freely delocalize. Moreover, for an atom in
the gas phase, the ionization energy is taken as the energy of an
electron in the outermost (highest energy) occupied orbital. In a solid
metal, the outermost electrons are involved in strong metallic bonding.
In metallic solids, the energy of the outermost electrons is increased
to a value called the **Fermi level**, which represents the average
energy of the conduction electrons. The Fermi level is sometimes called
the *electrochemical potential* of the electrons.

When a photon of an energy equal to or greater than the Fermi level of
the metal surface, an electron is ejected. The finding illustrates one
aspect of the nature of light, namely the relationship between energy
and intensity. Among other observations, Einstein noted that increasing
the brightness or intensity of the light does not increase the energy of
the ejected **photoelectrons**, but it does increase their number. This
insight into the energies of photoelectrons---namely that they are
quantized and always have the same energies---is the basis for elemental
analysis by a technique called **X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
(XPS)**.

In the traditional conception of measurements of the photoelectric
effect, the incident beam is in the ultraviolet or visible region of the
electromagnetic spectrum. Photons with wavelengths in this range can
knock loose electrons in the highest energy atomic orbitals, or at the
Fermi level of the metal. However, if a beam made of much higher energy
photons is used, such as a beam of X-rays, it is possible to penetrate
much deeper into the atomic structures. In XPS, a high-energy beam of
photons (X-rays, $\lambda$ = 0.834 nm, E = 1486 eV, from an aluminum
source) blasts the surface of the sample. The collisions cause many
electrons to be ejected. These electrons can originate from any
electronic energy level within the atom. Recall from your chemistry
class that these energy levels correspond to the levels of 1s, 2s, 3p,
and so on. The further inside the atom, toward the nucleus, the more
tightly held the electron, and thus the greater energy needed to eject
it. However, once the electron is ejected, it arrives at a detector with
*less* energy than those which were on the outside---i.e., higher
energy---of the atom. The reason is that it took a lot of energy to
dislodge the electron from the inner core, as implied by equation
(14.3).

Given that every atom of any element has exactly the same energies for
electrons, the energies of the electrons ejected create a spectrum akin
to a fingerprint. Thus, it is possible to determine the elemental
composition of a material, at least near the surface. (The technique
works for the first 10 atomic layers or so.) See Figure (14.5) for an

### 14.2.4. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy

A related technique to XPS is **energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy
(EDS)**. The major difference, at least operationally, is that in XPS
the incident beam is an X-ray and the emitted beam is made of electrons;
in EDS, the incident beam is an electron beam whereas the emitted beam
is X-ray photons. In brief, an energetic beam of electrons strikes the
atoms that make up a material, see Figure (14.5). These energetic
collisions knock inner-shell electrons into free space. So far, EDS
sounds a lot like XPS. However, it is not the ejected electrons are
detected, but rather *the photons released when outer-shell electrons
fill in the holes left by ejected inner-shell electrons*. These photons
are generally in the X-ray region of the electromagnetic spectrum. As in
XPS, the spectrum of energies produced creates a pattern unique to each
atom, like a fingerprint.

The EDS process is generally performed inside of a scanning electron
microscope (SEM, described in detail in the next section). The beam
scanned across the sample to generate the image also triggers the
production of X-rays. Thus, the SEM equipped with an X-ray detector can
simultaneously perform the imaging and the elemental analysis. It is
thus possible to overlay an elemental map on top of an electron
micrograph (image). In this type of composite image, different elements
are indicated using different colors. Electron microscopy plus EDS
analysis is a powerful tool to examine nanomaterials and the nanoscale
structures of larger samples.

#### Section 1: Invisible worlds
Materials and phenomena that occur on the nanoscale are, almost by
definition, too small for the human visual sense. Nevertheless, we
really do know their shapes, sizes, and compositions. To obtain this
information, we rely on techniques of **characterization**. Namely, on
the two closely related areas of **spectroscopy** and *imaging*.
Spectroscopy is the processes by which matter is bombarded with some
type of particle or radiation, and the particles that are scattered,
transmitted, or re-emitted are analyzed for clues about the structure.
Imaging techniques use a similar paradigm, but the end goal is not to
produce a quantitative spectrum but a visual image for processing (often
by the human brain). There are many modalities which combine
spectroscopy and imaging in a single instrument. For a video primer to
this chapter, visit 
>>>video(https://youtu.be/N18UhNQmI8o)

One of the things that differentiates science from everyday rational
behavior is that science needs special tools to overcome the limits of
human senses. We can only learn so much about the world from our senses
of sight, smell, hearing, touch, and taste. While we can determine some
things about the structure and properties of matter from our five basic
senses, we need to correlate these observations to information gleaned
from other tools. Nowhere is the augmentation of human senses more
necessary than in nanoengineering, where everything is way too small to
see with even the most powerful optical microscopes. For example, a
nanoparticle or quantum dot might have a diameter of 5 nm, but the
smallest wavelength of light that can be detected by the human eye is
about 400 nm, which corresponds to violet light. So, we are blind to
nanomaterials. That's why we can't see viruses billowing out of people's
mouths and noses, and it's also why we can't see the intricate details
of a computer microprocessor at the level of the transistor, even under
the highest possible magnification with a conventional microscope.

Thus, there is a conundrum posed by the diffraction limit of light. The
way to circumvent this problem is to use particles other than visible
photons, such as electrons, ultraviolet rays, X-rays, or even helium
nuclei. These approaches are analogous to optical microscopy in that
they use wavelike particles to interact with matter, and the image is
created from the ways in which light is absorbed or scattered from the
surface.

Such methods of obtaining images of nanoscale objects are not limited
only to modalities which shine---or blast---light or particles upon the
sample. The other major way in which information is collected about the
composition and structure of nanoscale materials is not by shining a
beam from a distance, but rather by physical contact or near-physical
contact, in methods that are akin not to the sense of vision but to the
sense of touch. Such approaches are referred to collectively as
"scanning probe" techniques. The feature that all scanning probe
instruments have in common is the use of a sharp object which scans
along a surface (like a vinyl or LP player). The tip can be used to plot
the topography, mechanical properties, conductivity, chemical
composition, or other properties of the surface. Finally, there are
techniques which use radiation not to generate images, but to probe the
structure of atoms, molecules, particles, and surfaces. These
spectroscopic modalities rely on the basic physics we have covered in
detail in Chapter 8, so we will begin here.

Subatomic particles like electrons, protons, and neutrons have a

Once aligned, a radio-frequency electromagnetic pulse can be applied.
Some of this radiation is absorbed by the nuclei, which flips the spin
from one orientation to another. As the magnetic moment goes back into
alignment with the field, some energy is released in the form of EM
radiation. This radio-frequency energy is transformed into a spectrum.
The spectrum that is produced gives information on the electromagnetic
environment of the magnetically active nuclei. For example, a hydrogen
atom, which has a total spin of one half because it has an odd number of
nucleons (i.e., a single proton), will resonate at a different frequency
depending on its chemical environment. In fact, $^1$HNMR is by far the
most useful and popular kind of NMR spectroscopy. For many organic
molecules, it is not necessary to use any other spectroscopic technique
to discern the structure.

$^1H$NMR derives its usefulness from the fact that every hydrogen atom
has a different resonant energy depending on the density of electrons
surrounding it. Thus, it is usually possible to piece together the
entire structure based on the precise energy of every hydrogen atom in
the molecule. Moreover, the **chemical shift** of the hydrogen atom is
predictable based on a handful of simple rules. For example, if the
hydrogen atom is attached to an electronegative element like oxygen, the
signal will be *de-shielded* by a predictable amount; if the hydrogen
atom is connected to an electropositive element like silicon, the
resulting signal is said to be *shielded*, also by a predictable amount.
Shielded and de-shielded atoms nuclei can be easily resolved by NMR
spectroscopy, with the resolution increasing with the strength of the
magnetic field. The strength of the signal (the area under the curve, or
the *integral*) also corresponds to how many atoms of a particular type
are within a molecule.

To convert from the standard output of NMR software, where the signals
are given in parts per million (ppm) to frequency of the emitted signal
(and equivalently, energy), one uses the following formulae, equations
(14.1) and (14.2)

(Equation 14.1)
$$\delta_{\text{Hz}} = \delta_{\text{ppm}} \times \text{frequency}_{\text{MHz}}$$

(Equation 14.2) $$E = h \times \nu$$

where $\delta_{\text{Hz}}$ is the chemical shift in Hz,
$\delta_{\text{ppm}}$ is the chemical shift in ppm,
$\text{frequency}_{\text{MHz}}$ is the operating frequency of the NMR
spectrometer in MHz, $E$ is energy $h$ is Planck's constant, and $\nu$
is frequency in Hz.

The NMR spectrum can also give information as to the mutual arrangement
or location of atoms attached to molecules at different points. They do
this by *through bond* or *through space* **coupling**. There are many
excellent references on the collection and interpretation of NMR spectra
and we will not go into here. See Figure (14.1) below for a couple of
examples of molecules matched to spectra.

### 14.2.2. Ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy, UV-vis

One of the most common forms of spectroscopy involves the use of
ultraviolet and visible wavelengths of light to probe electronic
transitions in the molecules or particles. Photons in the UV-vis range
tend to have energies commensurate with the band gaps of molecules,
particles, and surfaces. That is, absorption of photons that correspond
to the promotion of electrons from the valence band to the conduction
band (when talking about inorganic materials) or from the highest
occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular
orbital (LUMO) (when talking about molecules). Given that the energies
of photons absorbed correspond to the transitions of electrons between
energy levels, UV-vis spectroscopy is often called **electronic
absorption spectroscopy**. Figure (14.2) shows the key features of a
UV-vis spectrum.

(Figure 14.2) 
>>>image(UV-vis.png.0)

The UV-vis spectrum is usually plotted with absorption on the $y$-axis
as a function of either wavelength (in nm) or energy (in eV). The
convention used weirdly depends on who is plotting the data: chemists,
biologists, and some engineers tend to plot the absorption as a function
of wavelength, while physicists and other engineers plot it as a
function of energy. Since wavelength is inversely proportional to
energy, the plots appear as mirror images of each other.[^14.2.2] Note that
while the differences between energy levels correspond to discrete
photon energies, the absorption spectra nevertheless appear as smoothed
out curves, rather than lines. The broadening of the spectrum arises
first from the *density of states* below the valence band and above the
conduction band. Other effects that lead to broadening involve
perturbations of the energy levels caused by molecular collisions with
each other and with solvent molecules, formation of energy levels
spanning multiple molecules from supramolecular organization (e.g.,
crystallization), and fluctuations of the energetic levels due to
electrostatic (e.g., van der Waals) forces. Despite the broadness of the
absorption profile, it is common practice to take the onset of
absorption as corresponding to the lowest energy photon absorbable by
the system and thus equivalent to the band gap. Usually, one takes the
slope tangent to the beginning of the curve and extrapolates toward the
$x$-axis, as shown in Figure (14.2). The $x$-intercept is taken as the
band gap.

UV-vis spectroscopy can be used to measure effects beyond the bandgaps
of molecules and semiconductors. For example, the localized surface
plasmon resonances (LSPRs) of metallic nanoparticles often also lie in
the ultraviolet or visible region of the electromagnetic spectrum. When
placed in solution, colloidal metallic nanoparticles such as nanowires,
nanocubes, and nanospheres absorb and scatter wavelengths of light that
depend on the shape of the nanoparticle and the atoms(s) of which it is
composed. Recall that anisotropic nanoparticles like wires will have
multiple LSPRs, one for each dimension (a spherical or cubic particle
would have only a single resonance). The smaller dimensions will
resonate at higher energies than the larger ones. Thus, in solution,
where the particles are spinning and tumbling around randomly, all of
the LSPRs will be visible at once. However, if one deposits such
structures on glass or silicon using shearing forces during the
deposition, it is possible to get the particles to line up. Such
deposited structures will exhibit **birefringence**---in which polarized
light will trigger the LSPRs unequally. By using light with different
polarizations, it is possible to tease out the energies of the LSPRs
along the different axes (Figure (14.3)).

(Figure 14.3) 
>>>image(LSPR.png.0)

Finally, we note that such absorption behavior arising from electronic
transitions and LSPRs are not strictly limited to the range of photons
in the UV-vis region. In fact, many kinds of semiconductor nanocrystals
absorb in the near-infraried (NIR), and plasmonic nanoparticles with
dimensions of more than a few hundred nanometers also resonate in this
range. Thus, the technique is often referred to as UV-vis-NIR.

### 14.2.3. X-ray photoemission spectroscopy, XPS

We have seen above how photons can affect transitions of electrons from
one band to another within a solid. However, with high enough incident
energies of photons, electrons can be completely ejected from the
surface of a material. This phenomenon is called the **photoelectric
effect** (Figure (14.4) and was the basis of Albert Einstein's sole
Nobel Prize.[^14.2.3] In this theory, the kinetic energy of an electron
ejected from the surface of a solid is given by

(Equation 14.3) $$E = h\nu - \phi$$

(Figure 14.4) 
>>>image(photoelectric.png.0)

where $E$ is the energy (kinetic energy, because the electron is
moving), $h$ and $\nu$ are Planck's constant and the frequency of the
incoming photon, and $\phi$ is the **work function** of the surface. The
work function is conceptually similar to the **ionization energy**.
However, the ionization energy refers to the energy required to extract
the outermost electron from an atom in the gas phase, whereas the work
function is the energy required to extract an electron from the surface
of a material made of many atoms. The work function is always less than
the ionization energy for individual atoms of the same element. In part,
this difference arises because of the strong electrostatic attraction of
an electron to an ion in the gas phase; in a solid, the positive charge
left behind can more or less freely delocalize. Moreover, for an atom in
the gas phase, the ionization energy is taken as the energy of an
electron in the outermost (highest energy) occupied orbital. In a solid
metal, the outermost electrons are involved in strong metallic bonding.
In metallic solids, the energy of the outermost electrons is increased
to a value called the **Fermi level**, which represents the average
energy of the conduction electrons. The Fermi level is sometimes called
the *electrochemical potential* of the electrons.

When a photon of an energy equal to or greater than the Fermi level of
the metal surface, an electron is ejected. The finding illustrates one
aspect of the nature of light, namely the relationship between energy
and intensity. Among other observations, Einstein noted that increasing
the brightness or intensity of the light does not increase the energy of
the ejected **photoelectrons**, but it does increase their number. This
insight into the energies of photoelectrons---namely that they are
quantized and always have the same energies---is the basis for elemental
analysis by a technique called **X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy
(XPS)**.

In the traditional conception of measurements of the photoelectric
effect, the incident beam is in the ultraviolet or visible region of the
electromagnetic spectrum. Photons with wavelengths in this range can
knock loose electrons in the highest energy atomic orbitals, or at the
Fermi level of the metal. However, if a beam made of much higher energy
photons is used, such as a beam of X-rays, it is possible to penetrate
much deeper into the atomic structures. In XPS, a high-energy beam of
photons (X-rays, $\lambda$ = 0.834 nm, E = 1486 eV, from an aluminum
source) blasts the surface of the sample. The collisions cause many
electrons to be ejected. These electrons can originate from any
electronic energy level within the atom. Recall from your chemistry
class that these energy levels correspond to the levels of 1s, 2s, 3p,
and so on. The further inside the atom, toward the nucleus, the more
tightly held the electron, and thus the greater energy needed to eject
it. However, once the electron is ejected, it arrives at a detector with
*less* energy than those which were on the outside---i.e., higher
energy---of the atom. The reason is that it took a lot of energy to
dislodge the electron from the inner core, as implied by equation
(14.3).

Given that every atom of any element has exactly the same energies for
electrons, the energies of the electrons ejected create a spectrum akin
to a fingerprint. Thus, it is possible to determine the elemental
composition of a material, at least near the surface. (The technique
works for the first 10 atomic layers or so.) See Figure (14.5) for an
illustration of a typical XPS spectrum.

### 14.2.4. Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy

A related technique to XPS is **energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy
(EDS)**. The major difference, at least operationally, is that in XPS
the incident beam is an X-ray and the emitted beam is made of electrons;
in EDS, the incident beam is an electron beam whereas the emitted beam
is X-ray photons. In brief, an energetic beam of electrons strikes the
atoms that make up a material, see Figure (14.5). These energetic
collisions knock inner-shell electrons into free space. So far, EDS
sounds a lot like XPS. However, it is not the ejected electrons are
detected, but rather *the photons released when outer-shell electrons
fill in the holes left by ejected inner-shell electrons*. These photons
are generally in the X-ray region of the electromagnetic spectrum. As in
XPS, the spectrum of energies produced creates a pattern unique to each
atom, like a fingerprint.

The EDS process is generally performed inside of a scanning electron
microscope (SEM, described in detail in the next section). The beam
scanned across the sample to generate the image also triggers the
production of X-rays. Thus, the SEM equipped with an X-ray detector can
simultaneously perform the imaging and the elemental analysis. It is
thus possible to overlay an elemental map on top of an electron
micrograph (image). In this type of composite image, different elements
are indicated using different colors. Electron microscopy plus EDS
analysis is a powerful tool to examine nanomaterials and the nanoscale
structures of larger samples.
